data.summary: Law on fair redundnacy process (I'm still employed)
data.paragraph: For an organisation to fairly dismiss an employee by reason of redundancy there has to be both a genuine redundancy situation (which is not necessarily admitted), and a fair redundancy process. A fair redundancy process must involve a period of consultation with the employee, which must be entered into with the employer having a genuinely open mind to redundancy being avoided taking into account any suggestions the employee may have as to how his redundancy might be avoided. If the employee leaving at the end of the consultation process had been predetermined then the dismissal will automatically be unfair. I do not believe you consulted fairly and took my suggestions into account during the redundancy process, and accordingly any redundancy dismissal would be unfair.

data.summary: Coronavirus serious and imminent danger
data.paragraph:
Under Sections 44(1)(d)-(e) and 100(1)(d)-(e) of the Employment Rights Act 1996, employees are entitled to leave the workplace/refuse to return until the imminent danger has passed, to protect themselves and others from the danger.

There can be no doubt that coronavirus presents a serious and imminent danger. Indeed, the Health Protection (Coronavirus) Regulations 2020, at Regulation 3(1) state that:
“the incidence or transmission of Coronavirus constitutes a serious and imminent threat to public health.”
